Title: Nature-based solutions are critical for putting Brazil on track towards net-zero emissions by 2050

Resume.part01: This application describes the main results of the article
Resume.part02: "Nature-based solutions are critical for putting Brazil on track towards net-zero emissions by 2050."
Resume.part03: To investigate whether existing and expected national policies will allow Brazil to meet its net-zero GHG emissions pledge by 2050, we applied a detailed regional integrated assessment modelling approach. This included quantifying the role of nature-based solutions, such as the protection and restoration of ecosystems, and engineered solutions, such as bioenergy with carbon capture and storage. Our results highlight ecosystem protection as the most critical cost-effective climate mitigation measure for Brazil, whereas relying heavily on costly and not-mature-yet engineered solutions will jeopardise Brazil's chances of achieving its net-zero pledge by mid-century. Our analysis underlines the urgent need for Brazil to go beyond existing policies to help fight climate emergency, to align its short- and long-term climate targets, and to build climate resilience while curbing biodiversity loss.

0.name: BASE
0.label: Baseline
0.description: Baseline (BASE) - Deforestation continues up to 2050, with Amazon rates above 1 Mha/yr, on average, between 2020 and 2030. No native vegetation restoration. Pasture recovery and afforestation, in line with the Low-Carbon Agriculture Plan (ABC+ Plan). The energy sector considers energy policies currently in place.

1.name: FC
1.label: FC
1.description: Forest Code (FC) - Built upon BASE, this scenario examines the contribution of Brazil's Forest Code to decrease GHG emissions. Native vegetation restoration takes place in illegally deforested areas identified as environmental debts by the Rural Environmental Cadastre (CAR).

2.name: FCplus
2.label: FCplus
2.description: Forest Code Plus (FC+) - Built upon FC, this scenario eliminates illegal and legal deforestation and promote more than a twofold increase in the native vegetation restoration relative to FC. Restoration takes place in areas illegally deforested and identified as environmental debts by CAR, as well as in small farms that granted amnesty in 2012.

3.name: FCNZ
3.label: FCNZ
3.description: Forest Code Net Zero (FCNZ) - Built upon FC, this scenario allows the energy sector to go beyond existing and agreed infrastructure to bridge the gap to a least-cost net-zero GHG.

4.name: FCplusNZ
4.label: FCplusNZ
4.description: Forest Code Plus Net Zero (FC+NZ) - Built upon FC+, this scenario allows the energy sector to go beyond existing and agreed infrastructure to reach a least-cost net-zero GHG.

0.name: natveg
0.label: Native Vegetation
0.description: This class covers all unmanaged forests and native vegetation. Both the evergreen rain forest of Amazon, the deciduous forest of the Caatinga, and woody savannas of the Cerrado are included in this class.
